DOC.HEAD: Gas Fire Rages After Explosion at Utility Station
Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with blackouts, subway problems, four injured. Picks up 10th graf, `A fire....'
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and gas fire at a Consolidated Edison Co. plant sent flames and black smoke hundreds of feet over the East River today, injured at least four people and blacked out at least 128,000 customers. ``The lights dimmed really quickly, and then I heard a big blast,'' said Frank Wiles, 25, who works at a coal yard across the street from the plant. ``I have two trailers in the yard and it violently shook them. You could see bricks or debris landing around the area.'' The power outages caused extensive transit problems in the nation's largest city. Within an hour after the fire was reported at the Hellgate Station at 1:10 p.m. in the Bronx, it went to five alarms. By 2:15 p.m., workers had shut off a valve on a gas main that was feeding the fire and the 10-story flames subsided. ``When the valve was turned, the flames got smaller and smaller and smiles got bigger and bigger,'' said Paul Laddomada, 41, who works for the Department of Environmental Protection a half-mile from plant. Police Lt. Raymond O'Donnell said a Con Ed crew was working behind the station when a gas line was ruptured. He said at least four people were injured. At least one man was in critical condition after he was blown into the river by the explosion, then fished out by rescuers working in temperatures just below freezing, police said. The cause of the fire was undetermined, said Pat Richardi, a Con Ed spokeswoman. The Hellgate facility formerly served as a generating station then became a switching station and crossover point for electric and gas lines, she said. Electricity was cut off to 58,000 customers in the Bronx and 70,000 on Manhattan's Upper East Side, Con Ed said. The loss of electricity stopped subway service throughout the Bronx and all the way to the southern tip of Manhattan. A fire official said diesel fuel tanks at an adjacent bus station were in danger of exploding, and that some may have exploded. The Transit Authority evacuated its 800 to 900 people from a depot about two blocks from the Hellgate Station, disrupting bus service on at least 12 routes, said Caren Gardner, a TA spokeswoman. There was ``a massive rolling fire and explosion. The heat is so intense that you can't get within two blocks and police have set up barricades three blocks away,'' Gardner said.
